importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Trump cast doubt on the monthly jobs report in August, using the phrase 'people with common sense know it' to challenge the data.
Trump made a controversial social media post suggesting Chicago was about to learn why it's called the Department of War, which he justified as 'common sense'.
The article was published on October 22, 2025, detailing how Trump continues to use the phrase 'common sense' in political discourse.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article focuses on recent political rhetoric in 2025, particularly Trump's frequent use of 'common sense' in speeches and media appearances.

keyTakeAways: The phrase 'common sense' is frequently used by Donald Trump to justify controversial or norm-shattering policies, framing them as intuitive and widely acceptable.
Trump uses 'common sense' to dismiss opposing viewpoints as ideologically driven or outside mainstream thinking, often equating the opposition with 'nonsense'.
The concept of 'common sense' has historical roots in Thomas Paine's 1776 pamphlet 'Common Sense', which challenged British rule and invoked the lived experiences of ordinary people.
The phrase appeals particularly to rural communities, older voters, and those who identify with the 'Make America Great Again' (MAGA) ideology, signaling a return to a simpler, more traditional past.

While Democrats have also used 'common sense' in policy proposals (e.g., Obama’s gun reform, AOC’s health care initiative), Trump's use is more demagogic and expansive, often serving as a rhetorical tool to delegitimize critics.

The use of 'common sense' by Trump can obscure the reality of policy proposals (e.g., deploying National Guard in cities), which were previously unthinkable, by framing them as timeless and intuitive.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article explores how Donald Trump has repeatedly used the phrase 'common sense' as a core political strategy, particularly in justifying controversial policies and dismissing opposition as ideological or nonsensical. Drawing on historical roots in Thomas Paine's 1776 pamphlet, the article highlights how 'common sense' serves as a populist rhetorical tool that appeals to rural voters, older demographics, and those who identify with the 'Make America Great Again' ideology. The phrase is used across various contexts—such as advising pregnant women not to take Tylenol, questioning economic data, and justifying the deployment of the National Guard in cities—often to signal that a policy is intuitive, timeless, and widely shared. While Democrats have also employed the phrase in policy proposals like gun reform and healthcare, Trump's usage is more demagogic and expansive, framing opposition as outside the mainstream. The article concludes that 'common sense' has become one of the most powerful and controversial rhetorical tools in the MAGA movement.
title: Trump uses 'common sense' to make a political point. It has populist appeal
